body: PR hopefully covers all discussed in this issue.

-1 right now.

Well, I've looked at [the report](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/code-scanning/automatically-scanning-your-code-for-vulnerabilities-and-errors/configuring-code-scanning#editing-a-code-scanning-workflow).

Honestly, I'm not impressed. It has 1700+ new issues, many of them are completely off if we are considering that **we are talking about an IDE** which is **not an usual server-side** java **application**. At this point I see this generates more noise than value. 

I have to admit that I did not check every rule and findings there, so some of them might be valid and worth to fix, but then someone has to fine-tune the rules, before this would be useful.

I have released an update of the Jakarta EE 10 archetype including the enhancements from the PRs that were submitted by @OndroMih https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/io.github.juneau001/webapp-jakartaee10/1.1.0
Let's see if this would work better: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/6148
Duplicate of: #5069
Duplicate of #5069
This PR got replaced by #6160
Will be glad to give it a spin, once a built version is available. I hope this solved taglib 4.0 files issue as well.
The maven code might need some improvement. I'm not 100% sure if it respects the local maven settings (proxy, central repository override for company environments).
NB should offer access to its configured maven or at least the settings for it, no?

@morvael Indeed, but I'm not 100% sure I got the correct API.

~~Created a preview build of this PR: https://impl.it/NetBeans-dev-dev-ddb8fbfc0816b3179736c22f91679f1ac434e491-enterprise.zip~~

The fix in the currently used archetype is now released: https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/io.github.juneau001/webapp-jakartaee10/1.1.0

We can upgrade it while waiting for the new archetype

Help works, it nicely suggests new namespace name when completing `xmlns:ui="`
![info2](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1133953/0b86ef5a-d113-4a89-bdce-233b500b62f7)

The only thing that is missing is recognizing taglib 4.0.
@morvael Can you be a little bit more specific what you're missing?

re taglib

I have my own taglib registering a converter. It works as long as the declaration is set to:
```
<facelet-taglib version="2.2"
                xmlns="http://xmlns.jcp.org/xml/ns/javaee"
                xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
                xsi:schemaLocation="http://xmlns.jcp.org/xml/ns/javaee http://www.oracle.com/webfolder/technetwork/jsc/xml/ns/javaee/web-facelettaglibrary_2_2.xsd">
```

It stops working when switched to
```
<facelet-taglib version="4.0"
                xmlns="https://jakarta.ee/xml/ns/jakartaee"
                xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
                xsi:schemaLocation="https://jakarta.ee/xml/ns/jakartaee https://jakarta.ee/xml/ns/jakartaee/web-facelettaglibrary_4_0.xsd">
```

Even though it's just like described in https://jakarta.ee/xml/ns/jakartaee/web-facelettaglibrary_4_0.xsd

Tag turns red and attributes are no longer recognizable, and the xhtml file using the tag is highlighted with red icon.

There's also this logged in the IDE log, might not be because of your change, but since it mentions something Jsf related I thought I'll include it:
[exception.txt](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/11977340/exception.txt)

Not sure if this is related to this one following it:
`Even though the source level of .../src/main/java:.../src/main/webapp:.../src/main/resources is set to: 11, java.util.zip.CRC32C cannot be found on the system module path: `
I have IDE running on JDK17, project compiles with JDK17 though source/binary format is kept as 11. Might be unrelated NB bug :)
@morvael May I ask you to provide an example project? Would be easier for me to figure out what's going on with that.
I'll try to make one. Give me some time.

Trying to make vanilla Web Application with Ant, but it seems it doesn't know about any JSF libraries and doesn't allow to switch from JSP to Facelets.
![Screenshot at 2023-07-07 09-36-26](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1133953/41ed0427-99ec-4911-bcfb-57397c8f03cc)

Oops, a bug, seems in your new code (or it's old code):
![Screenshot at 2023-07-07 09-38-40](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1133953/7b9f7083-99ad-4f38-a827-058798a540f7)
`Cannot invoke "org.netbeans.modules.web.jsfapi.api.JsfVersion.isAtLeast(org.netbeans.modules.web.jsfapi.api.JsfVersion)" because "jsfVersion" is null`
So, going with maven project then, at least there wizard can be completed.

> Oops, a bug, seems in your new code (or it's old code): ![Screenshot at 2023-07-07 09-38-40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1133953/251671857-7b9f7083-99ad-4f38-a827-058798a540f7.png) `Cannot invoke "org.netbeans.modules.web.jsfapi.api.JsfVersion.isAtLeast(org.netbeans.modules.web.jsfapi.api.JsfVersion)" because "jsfVersion" is null`

That `Exception` is caused by the new code right. On the other hand I tried the same with NetBeans 18 which also seems not to work. So that `Exception` might new, but I guess the feature is already broken in NB18.

Edit: NB18 JSF 2.3 seems to work.
Lol, default maven web project does not compile as it pulls so old war plugin that it crashes without reflective access to some tree map comparator :) Switching project to use JDK11.

> This leads to the problem that we currently cannot update and bundle the latest Mojarra version as
> Java 11 is required.

I'm not the right person to be commenting on much of the JSF stuff, but this statement stands out.   There may be other reasons for preferring the approach here, but if the right thing to do is to require Java 11 then that's the thing to do.

> > This leads to the problem that we currently cannot update and bundle the latest Mojarra version as
> > Java 11 is required.
> 
> I'm not the right person to be commenting on much of the JSF stuff, but this statement stands out. There may be other reasons for preferring the approach here, but if the right thing to do is to require Java 11 then that's the thing to do.

I slightly agree, but from my understanding this won't be fixed soon (see https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/4904).

Actually I think to use the matching JSF implementation does make much more sense, as things like attribute completion suggestions or helper text relies on that.
Just proposing these attributes based on the latest or one most recent taglib description is not that ideal.

From my - limit - understanding I'd prefer to remove that bundled JSF implementation at all, but currently it's quite tightly coupled with the module.

I can't say I was that fond of the date approach before, less so now.  Can't we just use `computeIfAbsent()` when calling the map (validating the spec version is an `int` first maybe) and create the EA link as needed?

> Lol, default maven web project does not compile as it pulls so old war plugin that it crashes without reflective access to some tree map comparator :) Switching project to use JDK11.

That's a known issue which is - afaik - fixed master. My branch is not rebased to the latest master branch.

To get it work with JDK 17 just update `maven-war-plugin` to most recent version then it should compile.

Crazy, after I made this project both 2.2 and 4.0 taglib declarations stopped to be recognized (both in sample project and my core project). But the project works once deployed.
[mavenproject1.tar.gz](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/11979715/mavenproject1.tar.gz)
It's configured to use jdk called "JDK 11" and server "Wildfly", please change nb-configuration.xml directly if you need to change that. Should show something like this:
![Screenshot 2023-07-07 at 10-20-57 Facelet Title](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1133953/cae96be9-ccc0-4f6a-9c86-99b748d43387)

> > if the right thing to do is to require Java 11 then that's the thing to do.
> 
> I slightly agree, but from my understanding this won't be fixed soon (see #4904).

We have a few modules that require Java 11 - there are ways and means to work around this prior to all tests being fixed - _if that is the right approach for this_.

In vanilla NB 18 with old h namespace  it can see my custom taglib (provided it's in 2.2 version):
![info3](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/1133953/04b9efc6-d858-4b67-bfc0-4012dd15df39)

I have upgraded plugin versions and switched it to use JDK_17, so here is latest version that works in vanilla NB 18 (so without taglib declaration using version 4.0):
[mavenproject1.tar.gz](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/files/11980153/mavenproject1.tar.gz)

Wildfly seems to be pretty forgiving, and accepts old namespaces etc - it's just NB that isn't developer friendly.
This may be related to the bug report - https://github.com/apache/netbeans/issues/6075

OK, before and after shots on my VirtualBox Fedora install -

Before : 

![Screenshot from 2023-07-07 12-48-22](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/3975960/2c4ae22e-3bb6-421f-8dca-3e7ff3030781)

After : 

![Screenshot from 2023-07-07 12-45-19](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/3975960/33c5e288-dccf-418f-8e22-d54f2d88f918)

Seems to be OK to me.  @mbien can you confirm this fixes on your end?

can confirm that it works with the default `monospace` font on fedora (virtualbox/1080p/no scaling)
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/7db50333-427e-4723-b675-7a4525bbe00b)

Tried some more mono fonts like liberation, Noto Sans and Source Code Pro and they all worked fine too.


I noticed a second issue which seems to appear in the **output** window when you select something from right to left:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/543723db-ee84-4b1f-b084-bdd0dbf2aa7a)

Something is wrong with the selection. This too, is not reproducible on my workstation on manjaro linux, only on fedora. I am wondering if this is a similar issue just occurring somewhere else.
~~Build: https://impl.it/NetBeans-dev-dev-ddb8fbfc0816b3179736c22f91679f1ac434e491-enterprise.zip~~
@mbien LGTM get some stress because I forget to clean former maven version from external.
@ebarboni awesome, thanks. Lets get this in so that it gets some testing in before freeze.

@asbachb could you hook `enterprise/maven.j2ee`, `web.jsf` and `web.jsfapi` into CI?

failing tests can be ignored by adding them to the:
`test.config.default.excludes=`
property in `nbproject/project.properties` of the module. If most of the test works but individual test cases fail I suppose you could comment them out.

`web.jsf.editor` has too many failures atm be worth the trouble - thanks

Thanks @mbien Can replicate the output window issue.  Unlike the terminal issue, I cannot replicate with a non-monospace font on my main (Ubuntu) machine.  I had a quick look at metrics usage in the output window.  Curiously, if you switch on wrapping it seems to go away?!

So may be a difference in behaviour of these two classes?

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/core.output2/src/org/netbeans/core/output2/ExtPlainView.java
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/platform/core.output2/src/org/netbeans/core/output2/WrappedTextView.java

Anyway, let's take that discussion to a follow up issue?  Will merge this.

> Build: https://impl.it/NetBeans-dev-dev-ddb8fbfc0816b3179736c22f91679f1ac434e491-enterprise.zip

Looks like it works, thank you!

> I don't think that's fair. If you want to improve the situation get behind the code and start hacking ;)

I help the best way I can, by testing and commenting :) NB codebase scares me to do anything in it. I'm past my prime coder abilities time...
@mbien done!
Wildfly 29.0.1.Beta works as well: start/stop/deploy

the jboss-cli-client brings in a lot of classes that we don't need at all and might be problematic. While I agree that some cleanup should be done in the jars that the classloader relies on I'd rather avoid using that jar.
Thanks @eirikbakke yes, of course. :smile:  And stepped through with the debugger to see what was going on before and after the change. Been annoying me for a little while too.
Yeah, I was just too lazy to build and test it myself :-)
I tend to agree with @lkishalmi. The signal to noice ratio does not seem to be high enough.
@matthiasblaesing @neilcsmith-net everyone ok with this?
Thank you both for kicking in the right test and review.
@tmysik I've implemented 2 PRs again. Maybe, I think these don't have problems.

> the jboss-cli-client brings in a lot of classes that we don't need at all and might be problematic. While I agree that some cleanup should be done in the jars that the classloader relies on I'd rather avoid using that jar.

@ehsavoie what classes are you worried about or what is the concern? The server integration is a hack anyway right now.

But when compared to what it did before when it cherry picked the classpath:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/faf308b4da5e5f451ba6392f2388b123fa1ab4fa/enterprise/javaee.wildfly/src/org/netbeans/modules/javaee/wildfly/WildflyDeploymentFactory.java#L241-L255

Simply using the cli jar seems to be a more maintainable approach. Ideally, this all should not be needed if there would be a server independent tooling interface.

Can you share a screenshot or an error message. Your error description is a little bit too broad.

I tried to generate a project based on your description, but already failed on launching `DemoApplication` class. Is that the problem you describe?

In general I'd give it a try with most recent Java LTS version which is 17.

I have tested using the code in this PR and everything appears to be working very well.  Editing existing JSF views within each Jakarta EE project type (8, 9, 10).  Adding new JSF views within each project type also works well, creating the views with the correct namespaces for each of the corresponding Jakarta EE project types.  I will look through the code and leave comments.  Great work!

VisualDevelopmentUtil is in test code and doesn't really do a lot
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/faf308b4da5e5f451ba6392f2388b123fa1ab4fa/java/form/test/qa-functional/src/org/netbeans/qa/form/VisualDevelopmentUtil.java#L24

The class can be likely removed since its functionality is covered by JDK classes or other utils by now.

BTW you don't have to open an issue if you are planning to open a PR anyway.
I agree with it, will you push this commit? It's my first contribution and I don't know this process well

> I agree with it, will you push this commit? It's my first contribution and I don't know this process well

sure no problem. Going to push into your branch which will make it appear here.
Great, I invited you to my repo

Here's an additional test for `NPECheckTest` to prove the problem:

```java
    public void testObjectsRequireNonNull() throws Exception {
        HintTest.create()
                .input("package test;\n"
                        + "import java.util.Objects;\n"
                        + "public class Test {\n"
                        + "  public String test(Object obj) {\n"
                        + "    Objects.requireNonNull(obj);\n"
                        + "    if (obj instanceof Number)\n"
                        + "      return \"\";\n"
                        + ""
                        + "    return obj.toString();\n"
                        + "  }\n"
                        + "}")
                .run(NPECheck.class)
                .assertNotContainsWarnings("7:15-7:23:verifier:Possibly Dereferencing null");
    }
```

thanks but you don't have to do that since this is enabled by default when you open a PR:
![image](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/114367/4e8e97cd-bcc3-43ae-bc59-7125dc0b0cb0)

we can basically push into the branch you used when you opened this PR for situations like this here :)
New PR: #6160

@doitsexy @Jaswindermehta @prushforth could you verify if this happens still in NetBeans 18? Which tomcat version you're using?

Could not reproduce this with NetBeans 18, Linux, tried tomcat 10.1.10 on Java 17 and tomcat 8.5.90 on Java 1.8
I upgraded to NB 18, tomcat 9.0.76, and no longer have the problem, java 11.

> I tried to see the problem myself and indeed it is reproducible with:

+1

> Anyway. For the concrete case the minimal fix is adding `<build-prerequisite />` is enough.

+1

> I'm not sure, though that it is a good idea to do this, 

I see adding `<build-prerequisite>` as a proper fix. It says (in my opinion) _"make sure that module is **properly** compiled"_. Which it is not, if it is outdated.

> as next time the problem is a different module.

Probably. This kind of incremental issues is hard to spot and get completely right.

Good news: #4976 is fixed by this

The old namespaces should be detected. I suspect it's an error caused by thee previous exception.

Can you share your project somehow?

I also tested the dev build
JSF 4 is working fine with the new namespaces (Ctrl-space) AND also JSF code completion is OK (see 5522)
thanks for the modifications !!
Have a nice day !!
Louis
configuration : java 19, wildfly 29.0.0.Beta1 with Mojarra 4.0.2, windows 10
@pine3ree Reproducible. Thank you for your report.

Reverted "FixImports" changes with #6152 
It should be OK now.

Reverted "FixImports" changes with #6152 
It should be OK now.
@dil-it21 Please write an example code to reproduce it.

tested:
 - existing projects should keep using the settings they had before
 - global setting influencing gen style of new projects
 - local setting influencing gen style of listeners in that form

That sounds like a good idea and perhaps also use that factory for the top level tabs as well (editor and view tabs).

@mbien maybe you have enabled one of the options in following screenshot that are surrounded by red rectangles?
Then you're using multi-tabs implementation, which does not have this issue.
NetBeans has two implementations for tabs:
- tab control: only single-line on top edge (the default)
- multi-tabs: multi-line, top/bottom/left/right edges, ...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5604048/72222672-bd2d7d00-3567-11ea-8d83-2f3e777222e3.png)

@eirikbakke have you changed the global setting before or after creating the form? Because the global setting is copied into the form setting on creation. By clicking on the form in the navigator you should have the setting again in the properties.
